sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a sublimation reaction
message_1: What is the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) for the sublimation of solid iodine (I<sub>2</sub>) to its gaseous state at 1 atm and 298 K? Given the enthalpy of fusion of iodine to be 15.5 kJ/mol and the enthalpy of vaporization to be 41.3 kJ/mol.
message_2:
To find the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) for the sublimation of solid iodine (I₂) to its gaseous state, we can use the given enthalpy of fusion and enthalpy of vaporization. Sublimation is the process of a solid changing directly into a gas, bypassing the liquid phase. In this case, we can consider the sublimation process as a combination of the melting (fusion) of solid iodine to liquid iodine and the vaporization of liquid iodine to gaseous iodine.

The enthalpy change for sublimation (ΔH°sub) can be calculated as follows:

ΔH°sub = ΔH°fusion + ΔH°vaporization

Given the enthalpy of fusion (ΔH°fusion) is 15.5 kJ/mol and the enthalpy of vaporization (ΔH°vaporization) is 41.3 kJ/mol, we can plug these values into the equation:

ΔH°sub = 15.5 kJ/mol + 41.3 kJ/mol

ΔH°sub = 56.8 kJ/mol

So, the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) for the sublimation of solid iodine (I₂) to its gaseous state at 1 atm and 298 K is 56.8 kJ/mol.
